CHIT-CHAT LOCALS.
Gathered by our Reporters.

New Goods arriving daily at Fish's.
T. T. T. Try out our T. Walters & Sons.
H. Mitchell, M.L.A., Duke Lake, is in town.
Mr. Butte, M.L.A., is taking a tour through the country visiting his constituents.
Mr. McCrum, who has been in town on a business trip, is now back, having returned to his home in Duke Lake.
The public school at this end of the town has been well attended all winter; last night there were 26 pupils present, and an average attendance of 24.
Sergio Montgomery and Billie Walker are in town a few days ago, the former from Saskatchewan, the latter from British Columbia.
Sergio Montgomery has been employed in the detachment of Saskatchewan detachment of the North West Mounted Police.
The Indians have been winter goods will be sold at cost.
We are doing a Grey Flannel at $2 per yard, Lamb Caps for $1, Lambskin Coats, $2, Tweed Suits for $10, Ladies' Hats $1.50, Ladies' Overcoats $1. All other winter goods will be cut in same proportion.
Walters & Sons.

S. W. Vaillancourt is around getting signatures to a petition addressed to the Minister of Interior asking for a post office at the mouth of the South Branch.
The petition is being numerously signed.
Mr. Vanier, who lives at the mouth of the South Branch, has been asked by the Indians to take charge of the post office.
He will put two runs of stamps.
The tellers are changing in every tenth banker for greater safety, too late for chopping.

Glaucoma is very prevalent in this section, and many cases are brought here for treatment.
There has already been several horses lost, some of them burned or killed when the Indians had a big feed of glaucoma horse whiskey.
It is thought that something should be done to stop these people from using the damned cayuse, and also to prevent the spread of the disease.

I would like to call the attention of the council to the fact that they should provide a better place in the council chambers for their representatives to account of the proceedings of the council meetings.
Therefore our young men and women on the bench, who are the most likely to get into a scrape, to get nearer he had to content himself with the smallest hall, or else to wait until the council adjourned.
It is important to the interests of the clerk to make extracts from the minute book.
Please get a chair for the clerk.
The Hon. Mr. Justice McKeown held a session of the Supreme Court this morning.
The only case to be disposed of was the case of Mr. Smith vs. Mr. Smith (The Gentleman) charged with the larceny of four dollars from Russell & Davis.
The defendant was a man of about 40 years of age, with bad reputation.
After the charge had been read, the prisoner pleaded guilty to the indictment.
He was committed to the N.W.T. Police barracks for three months at hard labor.
James McKay represented the prisoner for the prosecution.
Mr. John Miller and John Little Cow, a Sioux, acted as interpreters.

Why not send reinforcements rising from caterers who want Rain will come soon?
A. H. Derry, Barnacktown, Ont.
says—I received a letter from Mr. Smith, who is now highly interested in the gold in the bend and catchment.
It will effect a cure very quickly.

Are you interested in the right and honors of the Order of the Garter? If so, apply to the Secretary of the Order of the Garter, who is now highly interested in the gold in the bend and catchment.
It will effect a cure very quickly.

NEW YORK

FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 1, 1889

SASKATCHEWAN INSTITUTE.
As will be seen by our report in another column, a historical and scientific society has just been organized in town under the name of the "Saskatchewan Institute." The formation of such a society marks an important step toward progress. It has been organized under the most favorable auspices; it has a wide field to work in and must if properly conducted be of inestimable benefit to the country and to the advancement of science and learning. It is fortunate in having among its officers members of much ability, of education and of literary and scientific attainments. During the winter months short papers will be read on various literary and scientific subjects, and in the summer the work of the society will be more particularly directed to field work. We hail with pleasure the organization of the Saskatchewan Institute, and trust that everyone in the district will take a keen interest in it and contribute what they can to its success. Now that the initiative has been taken and the Institute formed no scruples or fears should deter any person from joining and taking a deep interest in the work.

On the subject of railway settlement there seems to be somewhat blighted hopes. A report has come to hand evidently on good authority, to the effect that the negotiations between the C.P.R. and Regina & Lake Road have fallen through and that no contract will be signed with the latter company until after the present election. If such be the case this district will be in a bad plight, we have pointed out time and again that a railway is an absolute necessity. That without one we cannot remain connected except to starve. We consider that we are not being fairly treated by the Government in this respect, and that if some immediate action is not taken we shall lose our railway communications in this direction. If the same serious settlement will cease to exist. If terms cannot be made with the Regina Road an offer should be made to the Manitoba & North Western and to that made to the R.C.L.R. Railway, which if it is not sufficient we consider that a cash subsidy should be given to any line that will come into Prince Albert and Bitter Creek at once.

Another matter requiring the attention of the Government is the necessity of a post office and other public buildings at this point. The building now being used for a post office, besides being very unsafe, does not give the convenience and accommodation required. All other Government offices here are in the same fix. The Government pay about $300 per annum for the buildings at present in use. They can borrow money at five per cent, and $300 would pay the interest on $15,000. Ten thousand dollars would erect a block which would be ample sufficient for all purposes for a number of years, and then about $300 would be saved to the community. With such a block, and proper heating and lighting arrangements would be made in fuel, the buildings now in use are so poorly built as to require an uncalculated expenditure for heating purposes. If we cannot get a railroad the authorities will still do us this especial act; it will make a saving in the end to the Dominion.

After the lapse of seven months the expenses of the Legislative Assembly elections have been paid.

The official report just published shows a surplus of $3,000,000 in the Dominion treasury for the past financial year.

TERRITORIAL NEWS

FORT MACLEOD.

From the Gazette, Jan. 12.

A few of Mr. David French's friends giving him a banquet on Tuesday night. Lord Governor Royal will be present.

While Mr. A.F. Grady was making a Monday night, he had a fall tall. He suffered considerable from the effects of it Monday night.

The Queen on, Readers, adjourned from a new stage at Calgary on Saturday last, and the trip has created no little interest and even excitement in the town. The new stage is the first driver of an old Calgary stage, the proprietor being Mr. John Macdonald. The trip was made last week, the stage was loaded by police, barrel and trunk containing liquor was found. The whole carft was seen and taken to the police station, where the man placed under arrest. The team and wagon were released and taken to Stand- man's store at the same time. The man was told that the driver, Readon, knew nothing of the contents of the barrel and trunk. Neither he nor the pro- prietor of the stage was charged. The stage was delivered to the police station, loaded on the stage. They were delivered at the stage office in Calgary, and handed over to the police. The stage was fined $100 and costs and the team and stage, which did not belong to him, confiscated. A police constable was sent to Standman's store to take the team and wagon. Acting under orders Standman refused to give up the team until the bill for fine and costs was paid. The police went to the barracks for fur- ther instructions, and Sup't Macdonald was ordered to send the team and wagon. Standman still refuses, the police taking forcible possession. The case has been appealed. Mr. Haultain for defendant.

EDMONTON.

From the Bulletin, Dec. 8.

Still no snow, no zero weather, no thaw to be expected.

J.D. Wilson, of the H.R. Co., Victoria, has been appointed postmaster of Elkano at that point.

Application for a license was made yesterday by Joseph Gribbin on behalf of several half-breeds at St. Albert, who are said to be in a destitute condition. They are said to have been refused the Indian treaty in 1853-56, and who have never become entirely self-supporting.

The dog advertised as lost by W. Hirding, of Edmonton, was returned to him at Stony Plain on Saturday evening within six hours after the first appearance of the advertisement. The dog, described as a couple of months old, by Dr. Wilson has also been recovered. The moral is plain.

QU'APPELLE.

From the Vindicator, Jan. 17.

A cold wave has struck this part of the North-Western the worst. The thermometer touched 25° below zero on Monday morning.

Mr. Thistle, the bootmaker, has arrived in town and is busy engaged in building a house for the use of the looking club next season.

On the 2nd inst., J. B. Lash, agent at Battleford's agency, appeared before the court charged with having been employed by the employees of the Indian Depar- tment, in his agency, and presented with a sufficient bond to serve and an address.

The warrant against Mr. Karras, as coun- sel for Ward No. 2, the city of Edmonton, has been posted on the ground that he does not own the land for which he has been assessed, but has never having performed his entry thereof.

BATTLEFORD.

From the Herald, Jan. 12.

For a wonder, there were no permits by the last express.

Whooping cough is quite prevalent amongst the children in town.

The school board meeting continues tomorrow to Monday next for the purpose of arranging for the Protestant school district of Battleford.

On Monday's stage arrived Mrs. Morley and two children, from Indiana. On Wednesday she was married to James Grant, of this place.

Posters are now announcing the holding of an "Old Folks' Concert" in the recrea- tion room of the M.W.M.P. at barracks on Thursday evening, February 1st. The proceeds are to be devoted to the funds of the Presbyterian Church. The pro- gramme is said to be an interesting one.

CALGARY.

From the Tribune, Jan. 16.

G.C. King, who has just returned from Australia, says that he heard that the Cal Company were bringing in (G.C.) a color to work at the mines, is quite incensed. He says that the men brought in to do work which they could not do, and that the management of the company have no intention of work.

A magnificent bible in two volumes, beautifully bound, with Derek Hamilton's name on the cover, was presented to the reverend father superior of the Franciscan Fathers of Edmonton, by Mr. J. F. Hamilton, of Edmonton. The book was presented by Mr. Hamilton, who will carry the book around for inspection.

TOWN COUNCIL.

An adjourned meeting of the Council was held in the Council Chamber on Monday evening last. The members consisted of Messrs. Davis and Couns. Woodman, Donaldson, Goddard, Sanderson, Davis and Mair.

The Finance and Assessment, Board of Works, Health and Relief, and the Fire, Water and Light Departments made their reports; but not being in accordance with the procedure by law, were thrown out on the following motion being carried, after which the members returned to the mayor and the same of the councillors:

Moved by Coun. Davis and seconded Coun. Sanderson, that reports of committees presented this evening be thrown out as the committees are not legal.

The mayor ruled this motion out of order for the reason that the committees are legally appointed.

Coun. Davis moved that the report be received.

The mayor asked for the year and may, when all the councillors voted any; the mayor being absent.

The motion was then put and carried. All orders for it were from the mayor.

The following committees were then appointed:

Finance and Assessment—Woodman, Davis, Mair.

Board of Works—Woodman, Goddard, Mair.

Health and Relief—Davis, Donaldson, Goddard.

Fire, Water and Light—Donaldson, Woodman, Sanderson.

The mayor reported the action he had taken in connection with gladiolus houses. He had visited the new building on King street, and the collection of money had been made. The report as presented was adopted.

Coun. Donaldson gave notice that he would introduce a by-law to amend By-law No. 27.

The following committee were appointed:

John Smith—Chairman, John Smith.

The council then adjourned to meet again on Monday evening next, 4th inst.

THE HISTORICAL SOCIETY.

A meeting was held in the Nielson Academy on Saturday evening last to consider the advisability of forming a historical and scientific society. Mr. Jacquin presided and explained the object of the meeting. He said that earlier in the year a proposal had been made to form a society connected with St. Paul's Presbyterian Church, but they had decided against it because there was no one having a wider field. They had drafted a constitution to submit to this meeting and had decided that it was necessary to seek assistance to all who were likely to be interested in such an organization. He hoped the society would be formed and that it would be successful.

Short speeches were also made by Capt. Perry, Rev. Canon F. Van, Archdeacon Macdonald, and others, all of whom were in sympathy with the object of the meeting. Mr. W. R. Gurney spoke at length, saying that while he was fully in accord with the object of the meeting and would be glad to do all in his power to make such an organization a success, he thought it would be a mistake to attempt to form a society without a wider field. He thought it would be better to form a society connected with the church, as such a society would be more widely known and would have a larger membership.

The meeting was adjourned until further notice.
